reviewText:
A LITTLE OF WHAT RYZOM HAS TO OFFER
------------------------------

Ryzom does things differently to most mmorpgs, there is no *classes* you can learn all skills with multiple off branches, in total there is about 63 skill tree lines you can level each one to 250 if you sub, otherwise 125 without sub. that is alot of levels and months or years of gameplay even for a f2p player.

-----
COMBAT
-----

Ryzom has unique indepth style of actions / abilities you can actually edit and modify the way you want them with different effects, to combine into your own attacks or spells. its not your basic *press slash to slash a mob* you can input aimed shots to areas such as legs or head that add debuffs aswell as increase accuracy or damage of skills consuming more resources, further from this you have a few options on what your abilities cost to use them. for example, instead of stamina it could require some HP instead, or you can add special requirements like *skill is available after a parry or dodge. this all depends on how YOU build your skills.  some mobs can also disarm you in combat and cause effects, aswell as certain mobs being more resistant to different types of damage.


---------
HARVESTING / CRAFTING
------

In my opinion Ryzom has the best harvesting and crafting system from any mmorpg similar to the attack abilities you can customise what type of resource you want to look for, the quality etc, and when you actually find resources to harvest then starts somewhat a mini game, where you have different abilities that determine the quality and amount of resource you gain using *fast, or strong or healing actions* there is chance for gas explosions that will damage you while harvesting aswell as surrounding mobs so it's not an easy mode walk in the park, you may end up with Q9 q 20 q11 mats if you arn't paying much attention. certain materials have different stat factors aswell, for example materials for ammo have different damage or weight to carry more, speed, etc all at once. Mobs also drop materials for crafting

same goes with crafting, they can sometimes *fail* somewhat so you end up with a quality lower than you wanted.   you can customize your crafting to add stats like increased parry or increased HP etc and specalize in these, you need to learn each equipment seperatly you don't go *learn armorsmith... have access to all armor* you will need to learn to craft shoulder, chest, then quality, and ontop of this you can learn to craft other races armors and wear them.


--------
Other Bits
---------

Ryzom has seasons changes, weather and day / night. which can determine which mobs are available in some area's most other mmorpgs don't have this to the same extent.

Ryzom has different factions and reputation you can align to.


Despite what I keep reading, Ryzom does have missions / quests but its not linear story guided holding your hand like most mmorpgs and there is not 100,000 of them. if you don't want to do them you don't have to and they are mainly for fun / get some coin etc (beyond the starter zone which has tutorial quests to help you out)

there is death penalty for dying, which can stack up to 10x ( need to regain xp before you can xp towards skills) so dying does has its downfalls unlike most games.

As for graphics sure it is not the most up to date, but it is better then alot of eastern grind clones, and if you use gfx injectors / software like SweetFX to tweak it to hdr/enhance it yourself. personally i don't care about graphics on games, it is a silly thing to judge by, its all about game mechanics.

There is housing, guilds, achievements, occuptions seperate from crafting for moneys etc,

----------------------------------

after all this and more, if you still don't like the game then that is unfortunate, but the game won't be for everyone. however those leaving silly reviews like *this is ♥♥♥♥, it sucks, not an mmo, etc blah blah clearly havnt played the game past the loading screen to actually provide any reason or proof for their troll reviews.

If you have enough from your standard MMORPGs with Elves and Dwarves and Dragons and whatnot then you might want to give Ryzom a chance!

Atys, the world the game is set in is quite unique - the planet is basically one huge, living plant, inhabited by a wide variety of creatures. The characters aren't bound to classes, you can learn whatever you want, as long as you spend the time to level it up. The crafting system is quite complex - the economy is 100% player based, whatever you use will be made by other players or yourself, except for some basic starter equippment.

The ability-system is also noteworthy. You get to build your own attacks and spells too in a way: They are made out of elements you can swap and adapt everything to your playing style. For example you can raise the time it takes to cast a spell and in exchange make it cause more damage.

The community is by far the best I've come across in any MMORPG. The playerbase is mostly mature, friendly and ready to help newcomers. The way the economy runs teamwork is a must if you want to get your hands on really good equippment. Some of the places you get your resources from are pretty dangerous and should not be travelled alone...

That being said - yes, there is PvP in certain areas and guilds can fight for outposts, but it's your choice to join or not.

What else... NO CASH SHOP!

The only thing you *can* buy is a monthly subscription. The game is free to play up to lvl 125 - more than enough to see whether you like it or not - and with the subscription the lvl cap is 250. Also subscribers can rent an apartment in one of the cities PLUS they can own pack-animals - the only way to get more storage ingame.

So - go ahead, give it a try!

Ignore my hours played, I've been playing Ryzom since 2012. I can't recommend this game enough, but I wouldn't say it's for everyone. If you're looking for a straightforward carrot on a stick type game then this isn't for you. This is a sandbox game. It's for people who want a creative and challenging experience that requires you to think for yourself and encourages collaboration with other players. The community here is amazingly friendly, welcoming, and helpful.

The graphics might look a bit dated compared to some other games, but I am still in awe at the unique beauty and originality of this world. I love the interactions between carnivores and herbivores, and the animals themselves seem to have personality. Some herbivores will take an interest and follow you for a while, and some will actually pull aggro towards you to take it off themselves. Herds migrate with the seasons and there is a lot to learn about their different behaviours and traits. Some creatures resist certain attacks and some will swarm you if you attack a member of their group. You learn through experience which are dangerous and which are not, and which strategies to use for hunting different creatures. The wildlife can be ruthless and even an experienced player has to watch their step.

I see some reviews from people who have only played for a few minutes or a few hours and didn't like it. Ryzom has a bit of a learning curve and you really won't understand much if you just dip your toes in and judge it by your first impressions. There is a lot more to it than meets the eye, and I highly recommend giving it a chance. There is a complex crafting system and a huge number of skills to train. You don't have to commit to a class and can change roles in a team on a whim. Harvesting and crafting are complex activities requiring thought and planning. You can customize all your actions to make the most of your skills, rather than just pushing premade buttons.

The game is free to play for half of all levels. That's 125 out of 250 levels, for every skill in the tree. That is a LOT of gameplay with very few restrictions and is nothing to complain about. There is no pay to win" system where you buy stuff that gives you an advantage over other players. When I first started I played for about six months for free and was quite happy

recommended: and you shouldn't expect it to be like other games you've played. Talk to any experienced player and you will see that the game itself is like a beloved friend to them. It is well worth getting to know :)"

reviewText:
6/10 - The Harvester's Guide to the Galaxy

I've come back to this game for the 4th time now (I still own my disc from the orignal international launch).

For better or worse, nothing has changed.

Harvesting is still a unique experience, crafting is still fun (especially trying to craft a color-matching set of armor) and combat is still challenging.

But the quests are from the stone age of MMOs and the landscape has a lot of barren and uninspired places, the towns and settlements being the worst. And while the water itself looks nice enough (you can swim but not dive), everything underwater is barren land with not even plants or rocks.

Apart from the landscape the graphics haven't suffered that much over the years. The character animations are all natural looking and don't leave much to be desired and most mobs animations are quite convincing too. Harvesting effects couldn't look much better imo but the magic effects are a bit bland and combat effects are minimal - which makes for better FPS on older machines in return. The weather effects are also quite nice for an 'old' MMO.

Ryzom has a unique way of letting you create your own combat, magic, crafting and harvesting 'ablities' from actions, effects, upgrades and restrictions. Everything can be done as long as it's balanced. For example you can create an all-out attack that is very precise and powerful but eats up a lot from your stamina pool so you won't be able to use it often during a single fight. Or a 'pulling' spell that doesn't eat up a lot from your magic pool (called sap) and has quite a long range but is weak and has a long casting time in return. And when it comes to crafting, you can choose to imbue your object with a big bonus on your life, sap (spells), stamina (combat) or focus (harvesting) pool - or a small bonus of each. This versatility however has to be acquired with skill points that are earned in actually crafting something and also from crafting quests. Not a new concept but it works well (although it can become a chore some times).

Luckily there is no inter-dependency in Ryzom. Every character can harvest all the materials needed and learn all the crafting plans (kind of blueprints) for every single piece of equipment on his own. Specialisation still pays off, because it would take an unreal amount of time to train everything to the maximum. The system is simple but effective: If one wants to be a fighter in heavy armor wielding a two-hander, he can buy the blueprints and craft the weapons & armor  with a HP bonus - and if one wants to become a battle mage, he can buy the plans and craft armor pieces and amplifiers (gloves that increase spell efficiency) with a bonus to the sap (=magic) pool.

It is also possible to 'enchant' weapons so that spells and effects can be cast from them but it's quite complex and it doesn't pay off in the beginning to put a lot of time and skill points into it.

The AI has features no other MMO yet offers, like non-predatory animals walking over to you and watch you (out of curiosity) or large herds of animals moving across the map in natural-looking patterns.

Personally I can deal with all of Ryzoms minor flaws but there is still a BIG one - the inventory and shop mangement is terrible. Comparing items efficently is practically impossible and although there are filters both for inventory and shops, there is no way to sort anything - except for the games own enigmatic way.

It will be fun again for some time but it will not last for long I'm afraid.

Still I would recommend everyone to give it a try - if for nothing else, than just for the challenge of it. Surviving on Ryzom is not so much difficult but complex.

reviewText:
Ryzom is an old-style mob-grinding sandbox MMORPG. Like a survival sandbox, you start with nothing and have to make everything yourself.  The focus is on exploration and harvesting/crafting, and farming mobs. Some highlights:

- skill based, no classes
- all items are player crafted, there are no armor or weapon drops from mobs
- there are no quests, except some for cash and faction (the beginner island has tutorial quests)
- there are no instances or dungeons
- real day/night cycle, weather, seasons. These make a real difference. You might only be able to find a certain mat in the fall, at night, in the rain, for example.
- advanced mob AI, mobs migrate depending on season, and have their own routines
- consensual PvP, Outpost PvP wars, PvP zones that have the best mats
- housing, mounts, packers

Lowlights, this game is not for everybody
- no quests, no storyline. There is no hand holding, and a fairly steep learning curve.
- graphics are from 2004, scenery still looks good, character models are somewhat primitive
- tab targeting, no jumping, not action combat
- difficult to solo, except for diggers

The game is at its best when you team up and go kill mobs or bosses. Or when you saddle up for a night of exploration and digging. Or when a group escorts some diggers into the Prime Roots (PvP zone) in order to dig special mats.

I played Ryzom for a while back in the days, and play it again since it's available on Steam reminds me all the things that make me love this game. So I wanted to share my experience.

First of all, the universe is so compelling! The graphics may look a bit oldish, but the artistic direction is just stunning. The different feelings you may experience when traveling these unique landscapes can really move you. It is full of life, from the fauna to the weather and to the seasons.

Next, comes its community. For sure, Ryzom deserves to be called an MMORPG. Here, you will always find someone to help you, to hunt, to travel, to find something you are looking for, and so on. This is not a nowadays so-called MMO where you can just play solo. The force of Ryzom comes from the fact that you need the others players to progress, and that makes it a deep social experience. May you be shy at first, no worries, someone will propose its help soon, and friendships will come.
Another important point about the community is the roleplay. A lot of events are organized, by both players and event teams. This engages you so much.

Now, let's talk about the gameplay.

On one hand, I have to admit, the fighting system is a common one. But still, it's pleasant to play with. On the other hand, there are a lot of gameplay features making this game very deep and challenging to master.
First of all, the class-less design: this allows you to experiment with whatever you want. Want to be a master fighter? There are tens of weapon types, with their own skill trees. And not to mention, ending only one skill tree is already a challenge in itself. Want to mix some range weapon skills with healing skills? Do it, nothing will stop you combining the talents you have. What keeps it balanced is the equipment you wear. Don't think about doing magic with a heavy armor and a sword in your hands. You will have to put your light cloths on and your magic amplifiers to be efficient.

And about the peaceful activities: again, the harvesting and the crafting systems are very deep.
Harvesting won't consist in picking up some resources spawning here and there each 2 hours or so. Instead, there are dedicated skill trees which will allow you to gather rare resources. Also, you will need to learn where to harvest, at which time, and how to harvest efficiently. And every harvester has its very secret receipe that they may share with you.
Next comes the craft system, one that I never saw anywhere else. Here, the possibilities are endless. Creating the perfect sword will take you ages" of research to find the receipe. The statistics of an object all depends on the statistics of the materials you use and their genuine combinations.

reviewText:
I have played this game over the years and have logged at least 100 hours worth of game time independently of Steam. I am excited to see this title being available on Steam, and I hope my review is helpful to those interested in playing Ryzom.

The first section of the game is the tutorial island. This is a rather guided experience which showcases the features players can engage in when they leave. You are given quests by the master of a given discipline or the leader of the outpost. Many people enjoyed the layout and flow of this experience. Once you leave, however, the game changes remarkably. This is not to say it is good or bad, although many gamers can be caught off gaurd by it. You are no longer progressing via quests from trainers. Quests are few and far between and are NOT meant to be the rail from which one develops within Ryzom. The game expects that, once you leave the island, you are ready to engage with what you enjoyed there in the larger world scene. It is now up to YOU, not the quest giver, for direction. Ultimately, it boils down to grinding -- which is not necessarily bad. If you enjoy what you are doing, even if it is grinding, then you are enjoying yourself. Some people dislike it while others love it. That choice is yours to make.

The combat system itself is rather basic although combat is not sterile. You create your own skills through a basic formula of costs and spenders. For example, a cost could be adding a DoT while the spender could be you can only use it after you successfully dodged. A lot of possibilities are here although it will still condense down to a smaller amount of optimal skills.

Crafting is a beast all of its own. Each ingredient has a unique set of properties that, when combined with others, creates an unqiue collection of secondary stats which help refine various playstyles.

I could continue on, however, I think one can tell that each section of the game is like this. It's deep, yet someone has to peer through the layers to notice. The difficulty for a new player (especially those familiar with modern MMOs) will be to plummet the depth of the game instead of thinking the surface layer is all that exists.

Try it out. You may not like it. You may love it.

I have only played a little bit of Ryzom so far, a very little bit. That being said I like what I have played. Ryzom may be quite old, from what I can tell the skill system is different from most MMO advancement, with players leveling skills individually instead of leveling as a whole each character level. There are also no real classes in Ryzom, player chooses what to advance on there characters.

There are four playable races in Ryzom, the Fyros and the Matis, both very human like races, the races remind me of human, and elf races of standard fantasy games respectively. The Third race are the Trykers, a short dwarf like race, and the fourth and final race are the Zorais, a tall race who permanently wear a mask. Character customization consists of height, torso, arm and leg sizes, followed by facial options like eye size, hair style/ colour, and face/ mask scaling.


I don't know much lore about Ryzom yet, and I don't have much experience at all really past the introductory stages of the game, but Ryzom is a different enough MMO for me to strongly suggest MMO fans check it out.

TLDR: Outdated gameplay / Good crafting system.

I used to play Saga Of Ryzom back when it first hit the shelves. It was one of my first MMO loves alongside EQ and WoW. So naturally when I saw it on the 'Free To Play' section, I hit downloaded and waited with excitement.

First thing you notice is absolutely nothing has changed from the old days, and while that sounds appealing and nostalgic, the reality is a ‘clunky’ movement system, a horrendous UI, and the lack of many basic things that you’d expect from a MMO.

It dates the game terribly and just saps away all the enjoyment.

The only saving grace is what made Ryzom such a star back in the day. The crafting system is fantastic!!

If you’re looking for a deep crafting game and can look past the frankly terrible gameplay, go for it. Otherwise, avoid.

reviewText:
Ryzom is a great game with one of the best online communities I've ever seen. The crafting system is deep and character development is limited only by which skills you choose to level; there are no classes to limit you. The combat system seems simple at first but like the foraging/crafting system, has enough depth to it to make for interesting PvP for those so inclined.

The tiny starter island (Silan) does a good job of teaching you what you need to know to play, but the *real* game begins when you finish your lessons and go to the Mainland where there are far more opportunities, no matter what type of character you are trying to play. Hunters have a wider variety of prey, digger/crafters have better mats to dig, casters get spells that are unavailable in Silan... in short, Silan is only a glimpse at what Ryzom really has to offer. Any review based solely on a short time spent in the tutorial does this great game a disservice.

However, it's not for everybody. The graphics are a bit dated, the mechanics take more than 12 seconds to learn, and you can't get a maxed out character without grinding. If you are looking for a simple game with lots of eye candy that doesn't make you work for rewards, then Ryzom is not for you. But if you are a gamer that doesn't mind spending a few minutes learning who can tolerate graphics simple enough to run on a five-year-old laptop and is okay with not having things handed to you on a silver platter just for existing, it's well worth a look.

There are very few MMOs (RPG or otherwise) that I stayed with for more than a couple of months, but I've been playing Ryzom for about four years. If something is good enough for me to stick with, then it's good enough for me to recommend the game to others. So here I am, recommending that you give Ryzom a try.
